bow: tips for guiding dad to do the non fun stuff tldr im looking for tips to remove myself more from the non fun parenting stuff and putting more of that on my husband feeling really overwhelmed by being the parent that worries about the details and logistics of everything example my husband is great about getting the kids out for adventures outside just feel like do all the not fun parts the other day he takes them on very long hike while packed up our house for move if our daughter does poop by about 2:00 it will start to leak out and she gets constipated they got back around pm and of course she had not pooped and had probably been walking around with skid marks in her underwear for awhile so of course she gets bladder infection and is dealing with that the whole drive across country when we re moving and guess who has to deal with finding an urgent care getting her to take her antibiotics getting her to drink water making sure she peeing even though it hurts making sure she poops and drinks lots of apple juice so she can poop then need to make sure she takes probiotic so she does get yeast infection what tips do you have for getting your partner to engage in this stuff more so tired of being the bad guy who cleans up messes get it from his perspective if someone else was doing all the worrying sit back and do the fun stuff too but if just do engage and let things run their course then we end up with bigger messes that get to clean up send him couple articles on emotional labor especislly that one that called something like my wife divorced me because did do the dishes lol good call have talked to him about this concept before will look up that article his response is always that he happy to do stuff and he is but he truly does understand that the very meaning of emotional labor is that he needs to do the planning and logistics too do want to have to tell him what to do there reason at the end of the day exhausted from using my brain so much and he has all this energy to go for runs after the kids are in bed you say he happy to do stuff so ask him or tell him and don phrase like he helping you phrase it like it his job also because it is hey will you help our daughter out with her infection or our daughter needs your assistance with her infection tone says lot so keep that in mind but conversation and just bluntness goes long way does your husband even know that your daughter has to poop by 2:00pm do you stay at home while he works do you say can you find an urgent care and give her the antibiotics also those articles mentioned above are great he does know he just does seem concerned about it no we both work on the weekends am the one worrying about the poop good advice mannose works charm on the bladder infections great for all around urinary tract health for sure gave her this at first because we were driving and things were crazy this one needed antibiotics hope she feeling better utis suck there good cartoon about this too my husband hates reading articles but he actually read this one https www workingmother com this comic perfectly explains mental load working mothers bear sure this is redundant but communication really is key have this similar problem with my hubs and honestly just have to spell it out sometimes literally we sit down together and go over all of my to do list out loud he gets to hear how long it is and then wrote out what we agree is on his list and that way the expectation is set whenever feel really drained find it most helpful to talk about it with him before we go to sleep the lights are off we re both cozy in bed it feels like very safe space to share those things at least it is for us best of luck thank you have seen this before and it is great representation it the asking and planning that so exhausting will show this to him think this is the one you re talking about https mustbethistalltoride com 2016 01 14 she divorced me because left dishes by the sink this was good read communication can not be more important in partnership agree with moondruidmum try to make time to communicate with each other you re doing this child rearing experience together leave more often that how we did it started by leaving lists and sending texts to make sure he was keeping with the program held his hand in the beginning and slowly backed off could die tomorrow and positive my husband could absolutely parent our child solo brought it up lot when we would be home too ask him to do the not fun stuff like pack the day bag make lunch do bath time do the bed time routine instead of answering his every question id also make him think about it do need to pack snacks we are planning on being gone hours what do you think yeah would include that you both work in an edit there no excuse for his behavior thought maybe you were sahm and it was hard for you to turn it off and hand over responsibilities but if that not the case you should probably work on communicating and he on chipping in before you have to ask leaving is great idea did that this morning and it was good thing to do we have been talking about taking the kids to the park and he was outside working on something in the yard with his music blasting presumably waiting until had everyone dressed sunscreened gone to the bathroom bag packed so we could leave hopped on my bike and said just text me when you guys are ready to leave going to check out our new neighborhood he had been on hour bike ride already this morning as was leaving our son was pulling on my shirt and my husband said ok need to take shower too was like ok bye and biked off it felt good to let go perfect that sounds like good way to go hope he steps up it exhausting to do that hard stuff alone as dad this is really common issue and can largely be chalked up to men being socialized this way through their upbringing have lot of thoughts on this as boy you do realize how much you internalize the socially normal habit of men working outside the home and women working inside the home recognize this is heteronormative but most of the time these issues regard man and woman even as society has moved towards encouraging more equal gender roles over time we re still at place where men are congratulated for chipping in at home instead of equally co managing the household an example when my son was born received huge amounts of praise from friends and family for getting up at 3am every morning and giving my son bottle so my wife could get full rem sleep cycle received huge additional praise for washing her pump parts before bed and that crazy even today when ostensibly gender roles are supposed to becoming more fluid was being congratulated for doing what felt like *the absolute minimum* while my wife was doing 99 of the work the issue is that society as whole still expects too little from men and men internalize all of that messaging it in our upbringing it in our media and we hear it from friends and family we re congratulated for doing any chores at all then there are men like your husband who feel like they re going above and beyond because they ll do anything you just have to ask and according to society that is above and beyond the issue is that obviously that far from equal or equitable doing chores when asked does split the mental planning burden and men often shrug the emotional support burden for their families as well the justification is often have job so should be able to relax at home which is bullshit because while my wife was on maternity leave with our newborn she did way more work for way longer hours with *no breaks* than did at my real job men often are not taught to appreciate how constantly tiring child care can be when commuted to work was alone and listened to audiobooks at work got to take breaks when wanted and spend time chatting with adults got to eat full warm lunch my wife got none of these things big issue is that most men do really appreciate or understand the mental burden the concept of taking responsibility for things outside of work the health happiness and well being of the children the tidiness and cleanliness of the home the logistical and recurring tasks that need to be done to keep the family financially logistically and emotionally on track there are lot of articles blogs comics out there that discuss the mental burden that classically women assume it worth looking at those together and discussing ways to share this more equitably discuss ways that your husband can be mentally on at home too ways to look at the home as if it was *his responsibility* to maintain he sees dishes in the sink he does them the dishwasher is full he empties it the rug is dirty vacuum it food is running low add to the shopping list of *gasp* go shopping men do realize it but when they are saying just ask me and ll do it they re asking their partners to be their administrative assistants as well as their wives men need to learn to take inventory of their own lives and approach home child relationship issues like they are ultimately responsible ultimately what worked for me and my wife was talking about *all* of the work we do every day physical mental emotional and instead of using society expectations as starting point we looked at everything in front of us and talked about ways to split it more equitably side note it important not to simply divide up tasks you do all the pet things ll do all the kitchen things etc because then the mom becomes the *de facto* person responsible for new business talk about ways for both partners to see everything through lens of responsibility and communicate constantly about ways to improve went to the grocery store with my husband and made him chose the quantity of diapers we needed to buy had to hold his hand through the process he asked me how many we should get and was like nah you got ta figure that out remember our baby current weight estimate how many diapers we got through in day remember how many diapers we have at home estimate how much our baby will grow etc idiots yes thank you love your last line you tell me like you re an adult this is also something to introduce as your kids get older so they can function solo that so great good for you love seeing this stuff hubs and came to the realization that his parents never said what do you think when he asked questions he already knew the answer to they just answered him again and again this is part of his issue as an adult instead of thinking things through he defaulted to asking me even if it something answered 3x that week the first step was realizing it an issue and now we work together to break that habit for him we ask our three year old what he thinks the answer is if it something he already knows all the time now need him to not ask his wife what time family dinner is next weekend 20 times in week love that you already tried leaving also suggest finding few tasks to start with that he can totally own find that if my husband and try to split one task end up just taking it over so have to turn something totally over to him kid wants to play soccer—he in charge of it he can research the available league clubs register her buy the gear and make sure the gear is washed and in her bag the night before ll help drive to it this has led to him being in charge of few other activities like swim lessons it goes back to when was pregnant he researched car seats and researched bassinets and sleep sacks after you give him few tasks and he sees how much work is in one thing like soccer there the registration tracking all the emails from coaches the gear keeping it clean and in one place etc then you can have conversations about doing more of these for all aspects of life removed so now that this has happened will he forget the poop thing like will this thing happen again if not then ok he capable of growth but if so if going forward he doesn see this as an issue then you ve got bigger problem on your hands and why do you have to be the one to find urgent care or do the follow up stuff having reached that point why does it fall to you get it tend to carry most of the emotional labor around our house too ve learned to let go with the stuff that won hurt her tell my husband to get her dressed and come what may if we re doing something local ll put him in charge of packing her bag but again they re tasks that have to tell him to do sometimes don and he ll be like are we going to and shrug like eh when the toddler gets dressed guess but it hard one thing that has helped me is don see us as equal parents if you re going to make me the manager then the manager which means in charge of kid related things so if say we need more swimsuits then no arguing yes she has 12 but its summer this yes do more of this it has made the difference on break from studying at the library and ll be here until about an hour before dinner so that can play catch up on school stuff that got behind on while was solo parenting while he was out of town for work it good for him all say is ok it such and such time leaving you ll want to wrangle him otherwise he ll try to escape as leave and no his routine has changed at all while you were gone then out the door obv the last part is because he got home last night after being gone for weeks and when they re barely heading into toddlerhood it can change that quickly amp x200b ve also seen some friends have success with they sit down as couple plan out the week weeks or month and included in that is who is handling the logistics for what who is doing what chores and it gets decided as team so maybe have weekly night meeting once kids are asleep where this is decided if he balks and says he ll do what asked point out this is mcdonald you re not his manager this is partnership which means equal investiture and shared thank you for this this is my method too love my lists but consider managing stuff my responsibility think that what she trying to avoid though she does want to have to do the thinking for him omg thank you for this post you have nailed what is going on right now in my life my husband what is needed for each other this is just what works in my family it sounds like you are very busy but it also really sounds like you guys would benefit from therapy either together or solo my husband and have adhd inattentive type and it can be very difficult you did say but it sounds like your husband has it too amp x200b feel like us double adhd couples have to resolve things differently we have rejection sensitive dysphoria so your husband getting huffy and you being able to sense his upset seems like an example of both of you taking things too personally he upset that you rejected his breakfast offering and you re upset that he cooked things that he should know you wo eat it reminds me of the time my husband told me he was going to cook me very special meal that evening and it was mac cheese with tuna amp x200b something that strikes me as odd is that you are worrying about his eating habits and his need to balance work and home the one that works in my family and it super stressful being the only one bringing income sometimes feel like all do is work finding balance for your husband truly might be an impossible task for the time being also eventually gave up on trying to influence my husband eating habits and we are all much happier it really not the end of the world if you guys are not eating the same meals amp x200b my husband and had one crisis where we nearly separated over the division of labor question we both had to acknowledge ways in which we were being neglectful of the other but it made us lot stronger and more ready when our kid came along we have both landed in therapy since the birth though because having baby was lot more stressful than we thought and also brought up some weird issues with family and work that we thought we dealt with
